subject: Cybersecurity
title: Digital Sovereignty: Who Controls Your Country's Data?
description: One-minute skill: Digital Sovereignty: Who Controls Your Country's Data?.

hook.text: Most of the world's data flows through American servers. Some countries say that's a national security threat.

buildup.text: Data localization laws require data about a country's citizens to be stored within its borders. Russia, China.

discovery.text: Cloud Act (2018) lets US law enforcement access data stored by US companies anywhere globally, alarming.

twist.text: The EU's Schrems II ruling invalidated EU-US data transfers because US surveillance laws don't meet EU.

climax.text: Digital sovereignty pits national security against global internet freedom. The open internet may fragment.

punchline.text: The open internet may split into national walled gardens.

quiz.question: Why did the EU's Schrems II ruling invalidate EU-US data transfers?
options: US internet speeds were too slow
US surveillance laws didn't meet EU privacy standards for protecting personal data
The EU wanted to build its own internet
